header.aside: What happens when you combine mousse au chocolat-framboise and a protein smoothie? Chocolate-Raspberry Truffle Protein Fluff of course! This 3-ingredient recipe is so incredibly simple and low-fat, you won't believe it's dessert.

section.p: One of the first desserts I learned to make when I was 14 years old was chocolate mousse. I loved the light, airy, fluffiness of the consistency, combined with the creamy, rich and buttery-chocolate flavour. I even slipped a bit of Bailey's liquor into it, hoping my parents wouldn't notice.

So when the new Cellucor COR-Performance Chocolate Raspberry Truffle flavoured whey protein powder arrived on my doorstep (thank you Bodybuilding.com!) I was over the moon and terribly excited to try a new recipe with this flavour. I decided to try making protein fluff, which is basically a protein smoothie whipped into mousse. Using an electric whisk, the consistency changes enough to make it so stiff yet fluffy, you have to eat it with a spoon.

figure.figcaption: Protein-fluff dessert, decorated in a wine glass

td.a: Cellucor COR Performance Whey Protein, Chocolate-Raspberry Truffle,

tr.td: any vegan or low-fat milk (I used lactose-free low-fat milk)
Semi-sweet vegan dark chocolate chips (optional, for garnishing)

section.p: 3 ingredients for an incredibly simple, quick & almost fat-free chocolate-raspberry mousse. Delicious enough for dessert, with enough protein to substitute a protein shake and easy enough for beginners to make under 10 minutes.

To up this dessert's fluff-factor and to make the fluffiness last longer, add the optional ingredient of guar gum, which acts as a thickening agent. (Traditional protein fluff recipes use xanthan gum, however, a lot of people are sensitive to this and react badly. This makes guar gum a favourable substitute.)

tr.td: Put aside a few raspberries and the optional chocolate chips for garnishing last.
Blend the rest of the ingredients together in a high-speed blender until smooth and creamy.
Transfer blended mixture into a large bowl or pot, and whisk on high-speed setting using an electric whisk.
Pour smoothie into glasses and garnish with leftover raspberries and chocolate chips.
Grab a spoon and dig in to this frozen, fluffy treat!

section.p: As mentioned, using guar gum or xanthan gum will increase the fluffiness. However, I have heard that using casein protein powder is even better than whey for achieving light, airy and mousse-like consistencies. (Forget using vegan protein powders for this kind of recipe, the consistency will not turn out right at all.) For my next protein fluff recipe, I will try using Myprotein Micellar Casein protein powder.
